positive.review:
A diamond in the rough that unfortunately requires a lot of work to turn into a real gem.

A disclaimer: I have been having fun in flight simulators since Flight Unlimited 2, I am that old. My first XPlane was version 6 and the first time I saw Microsoft Flight SImulator II was as a kid on Atari and quite frankly I never cared much for it.

There are many issues with this sim. The user interface is abysmal, menu controls are the worst I have ever seen and the flight dynamics and systems depiction of most of the planes that come with the sim is very lacking (ironically one of the best planes in the sim is the default Cessna 172, but I think the devs can recite the POH of that plane in their sleep). 

ATC is... well, it's so bad that I just turned it off. I fly on PilotEdge, VATSIM and SayIntentions, but even Flight Unlimited 2 had a much more superior ATC system and that was more than 20 years ago. Setting controls is a chore and only after a thousand hours in I am starting to grasp the insanity of the mind behind it. Career mode, while it's something I very much hoped for, is feature-wise below the standards of any already existing career addons, like the old FSEconom. The only thing that is positive about it is the integration of aircraft state into the career module - if you land rough, you will eventually see it in the mechanic report.

I will not judge the actual physics. Not even real pilots are really qualified to do that, so take all youtube vids of real and phony pilots saying that this is that has 100% realistic handling with a huge grain of salt. To me, it's realistic enough. Most of the flight envelope is depicted really well and the rest is in the hands of aircraft developers.

However, once you spend time (and money) on getting a few essentials down, this is an absolute work of art. I would say that behind all the undercooked and broken stuff there is a labour of love from people who have flying airplanes in their hearts. But you will need to:

- forget about any version above the Standard one. I own premium deluxe. Not worth the money.
- invest in a couple of top quality planes from top developers. A2A, Black Square, PDMG, Fenix, Taog just to name a few.
- Personally I cannot feel any immersion from flying on a pad or on keyboard. Even a simple joystick with analog throttle and perhaps a twist stick will make it good.
- Find an ATC system of your liking if you feel like you need one. I can't fly without it because it adds that bit of pilot workload that just makes it interesting.
- Try to use one of the addon career modules. Some are free, some are paid. The bottom line is to have a reason to fly from one place to another, perhaps with some persistence. I am a member of Walker Air Transport which provides me a lot of ready routes and inspirations.
- Learn about how all this works in real life, otherwise the utility of floating an arcade plane over bing maps will cease to be a novelty rather soon.
- There are a lot of quality of life improvements on addon websites too.

If it sounds like a lot of work, then yes, but it's an investment that is paying off, at least for me. I fly both MSFS 2024 and Xplane 12 on a regular basis, spent more money on virtual planes and control systems than I care to admit. But boy, do I have stories to tell, like the time I crossed over Mongolia in a DC-3 Dakota on a round-the-world trip over the Himalajas... or made an ILS approach to Cracow airport in an absolutely abysmal zero visibility conditions in a conga line of other virtual planes on VATSIM... or just took off in a small biplane and flew over Yosemite... or cruised at FL400 in a fast business jet... or crossed the Atlantic in planes that were barely designed to do so...

My first time with a flight sim, and I find it interesting. I have only played career so far.
I'm happy i read reviews before paying a rather steep price for the game, because the complaints about bugs are true, and you need to acquiesce this until the developers get all these issues sorted.
A full year after release, and you still have a game in this current state:
-Game crashes to windows rather often
-You can get punished in a mission for action you have not done, before you even touch the controls.
-Bugs with the flight navigation log.
-etc.

You can learn a good amount about avation, but dont expect it to be extremely comprehensive in terms of the teaching.
Be prepared to search and study materials yourself outside the game, and then try out stuff in the simulator.
For example how to use the navigation systems in the planes, traffic patterns, etc.

The pace of the game feels like a grind too slow for my liking. It takes too much effort to earn credit in order to progress the game.
Yet, I still keep playing because i keep learning new things almost for each gamesession.

Overall I recommend the game, using a PS4 controller. 
I have learned things about aviation i never heard off, and I feel that you can actually save a serious amount of money in real pilot training, if you have a desire to acquire a real pilots license, due to the familiarity you get with aviation via this game.

The graphics looks nice (above altitude 1.000ft), 
you can disable the assists for the full experience, 
and you can interact with nearly all of the buttons in the cockpit, if you choose to handle the vehicles fully by yourself.

Excellent Core Experience, Critically Undermined by Core System Bugs
Recommendation: Not Recommended (Until critical issues are resolved)
I have spent over 80 hours in this simulation and genuinely love the core experience, the atmosphere, and the new Career Mode. It is, at its heart, a thoroughly enjoyable and engaging simulator. The sense of progression is rewarding, and reliable aircraft like the Cessna 172 Skyhawk fly beautifully.
However, the experience is severely and fundamentally broken by critical system failures and control input conflicts that make complex missions an unreliable, frustrating gamble. This is not acceptable for a flight simulator.
Critical, Game-Breaking Issues:
 * Unreliable/Corrupt Throttle Control:
   * Throttle control becomes completely unusable or "stuck" in crucial flight phases (e.g., final approach/landing). This issue is prevalent on higher-tier planes like the Cessna C400 Corvalis TT and the Bonanza G36.
   * This failure is unpredictable, resulting in a total loss of power control right before touchdown, leading to guaranteed crashes and devastating Reputation loss. The fact that the engine sputters or cuts out, despite correct Propel Pitch and Mixture settings, confirms a deep-seated bug.
 * Unacceptable Control Input Conflicts:
   * The system fails to support a combined control setup. It effectively forces the user to choose between Keyboard and a dedicated Yoke/Controller.
   * It is impossible to reliably map complex commands (e.g., Autopilot functions) to keyboard combinations while simultaneously using a yoke, as the system struggles to process these inputs without conflict. This hinders essential pilot workflow and forces reliance on the mouse in critical situations.
 * Inconsistent and Bugged Navigation Guidance:
   * There is a consistent and dangerous mismatch between navigation systems: The visual "Flying Patterns" (boxes/guides) frequently vanish or conflict severely with Air Traffic Control (ATC) instructions.
   * Example: Being instructed to "maintain 15,000 feet" by ATC while the visual guide simultaneously demands a rapid descent for a landing a few kilometers away. This forces the player to guess and risks a mission-ending crash.
 * Unexplained Flight Path Failures:
   * Even when lined up perfectly for the final approach, the aircraft will sometimes perform an uncommanded, sharp, and aggressive turn (swerving) or dive that cannot be corrected, leading to a crash. This suggests a failure in the underlying simulation model (e.g., the Rudder Connection bug on damaged aircraft).
Conclusion:
The dedication to realism in the world and the core flight model is outstanding, but the total unreliability of the essential control systems and navigation guidance makes the game unplayable for serious career progression. Until these fundamental bugs—especially the throttle issues and control conflicts—are fully addressed, this remains a title with incredible potential, but currently delivers an unacceptable and deeply frustrating experience.

I do understand that not everyone might have experienced this types of bugs or similar experiences in some cases.

Many popular addons have been converted to work and in my experience the sim both performs better and has better visuals, although my terrain and object level of detail sliders are set quite low as they are in 2020, to be able to have reasonable performance. With that out of the way it's definitely smoother and prettier. Your performance mileage may vary, and as I mentioned, there are still numerous issues all over the place that plague this franchise in general. But I'd say with the recent SU4 beta I'm pretty content with moving my addons over from 2020.

Helicopter Career Mode – Still Broken, Still Unplayable

I hopped back into the game recently, hoping that maybe, just maybe, after a year they’d fix at least some of the problems. Nope. Every single issue that was there at the start of 2025 is still alive and kicking.

The helicopter side of Career Mode is honestly a disaster. About half of the missions are straight-up unplayable. You can be hovering perfectly still — engines running smooth, no warnings, everything fine — and the game just decides, “You crashed.” Mission failed. Thanks for playing.

Or even better: you spend 30–50 minutes on a mission, land perfectly, and the game refuses to recognize it. The mission just sits there, mocking you. There’s no way to end it, no payout, nothing. Your only option? Abort and lose everything.

And the loading times… oh boy. You can make coffee, take a shower, maybe learn an instrument, and it’ll still be loading. Then when it finally starts, you get 45 minutes of smooth flying followed by a random invisible wall ending your career.

It’s just painful how inconsistent everything is. Some missions bug out completely, others don’t trigger at all, and overall it feels like the helicopter part of the game was abandoned halfway through development.

I want to like it. I really do. Flying helicopters is fun — when it actually works. But right now, it’s just frustration wrapped in pretty graphics.
If you plan on playing Career Mode with helicopters: don’t. Unless you enjoy yelling at your monitor and questioning your life choices after every failed landing.

I think it’s time for me to throw in the towel on this one. I held out hope for a long time, believing the team would eventually deliver. I was genuinely excited for this game — finally, a flight simulator that could bring career progression, mission structure, and real economic depth into the experience. It had the potential to create incredible immersion and inspire a whole new wave of aviation interest through YouTube series and community projects.

But I’m deeply disappointed. I feel fooled by the way this release was presented. The pre-release communication made it seem like the developers had a solid vision and a genuine passion for aviation and simulation. I believed in them — enough to buy the Aviator Pack to support the project because I truly wanted it to succeed. Yet almost a year later, the game still doesn’t feel anywhere near release-ready.

It’s a real shame. This could have been a fantastic game if it had delivered on its promises. Even the free flight experience feels unstable and incomplete. I delayed writing this review because the developers’ feedback after launch seemed positive — as if they had a plan and were actively fixing things. But at this point, it feels more like a broken promise than a work in progress.

I want to change this review someday. I still hope that one day this will become the game I believed I was buying. Please — make it into the simulator it was meant to be.

Waiting Simulator 2024

Do you ever find yourself in the mood to waste hours of time playing video games, but are tired of engaging with the content to do so? 

Do you ever come away from a gaming session exhausted because you got too much done per unit of time wasted? 

This game solves these problems. By taking 30 minutes to boot from the time you launch the game, locking you in the menu for hours while it loads your flights, and making you go back and forth trying to get basic things to remember your wishes (like the hair color of your pilot, or the time of day you set for the flight), you can waste hours of your life without ever actually experiencing any fun! 

Very rarely do we see a game that innovates on how you interact with the game: you get your standard keyboard and mouse, and you press buttons to make things happen. Microsoft is taking us on an avante garde journey as they incorporate the rest of your house into the interactive experience. Watch as you get up from your chair to clean your room, wash the dishes, make a phone call, or browse reddit waiting for the game to load the most basic assets, from menu images to a flight you literally just loaded a moment ago!

I've never not played a game so much before!

The game crashes constantly and randomly. It doesn’t autosave anywhere, so you lose all of your flight progress. My most recent crash was because I was adjusting the mixture — what an edge case the devs never saw happening!

The training missions don’t explain anything at all. I’m not versed in a B737; you can’t expect me to know exactly what all the acronyms, buttons, and checklist items mean. You get docked points because you aren’t a seasoned jet pilot, with no explanation.

Career mode will dock you points for no reason. I’ve had points taken off for “entering a taxiway” on a runway where I had to turn around and couldn’t do so without running off the tarmac a bit. It’ll also only give you 80–90% for landings even when they were textbook.

Some missions have you flying outside of your plane’s capabilities — spawning you in a 172 and asking you to take off and climb a mountain at a rate higher than the aircraft can achieve. You fail the mission if you deviate from the path.

The controls are way overcomplicated. I have a button on my throttle to enable/disable NAV AP. For some reason, each aircraft has this exact same function listed differently in the controls menu. Even after setting general controls and “copying to all aircraft,” there are several areas where the same key/button needs to be bound multiple times for most aircraft to recognize it.

Sometimes autopilot doesn’t work. Sometimes your throttle gets stuck at TOGA. Enabling NAV mode on AP will have your aircraft oscillate endlessly, even though you were already on the line when enabling it. Sometimes the V/S beep in gliders gets stuck at a certain tone no matter what. Sometimes the sim wants you to taxi to parking, but the parking spot is 180 degrees from where you’re facing and there’s no way to get there — so you just park the wrong way and chop the marshaller in half with your prop. Sometimes the hold short box isn't in the right place so you get penalized for overshooting it. then it repeats that message and continues to ding you over and over again, while asking you to disable the parking break (already disabled) while in the air.

[h2]TL;DR:[/h2]
[h3]Free Flight:[/h3] Stunning, smooth, magical.
[h3]Career Mode:[/h3] Bug buffet served daily! Do bring patience.
[h3]Verdict:[/h3] I love it too much to lie...can't recommend it.
[hr]
[/hr]
[h1] I absolutely love Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024.[/h1] 

Let's get the obvious out of the way first: the graphics are jaw-dropping. The first time I loaded into Free Flight and watched the sunrise over the clouds, I just sat there, grinning like a kid. You can see reflections in the cockpit glass, light bouncing off the wings, and tiny cars moving below, it's insane. There's no point in even debating it: [b] it’s absurdly beautiful![/b]

[h3]Free Flight mode?[/h3]
Absolute chef's kiss. It's relaxing, immersive, and everything I ever wanted from a flight sim. You can just pick a plane, pick a place, and go, no stress, no nonsense. Sure, there are a few small glitches (nothing's perfect), but nothing major. The kind of issues you can solve by taking a deep breath, grabbing a snack, and reminding yourself you're basically flying a digital Boeing from your desk.

And, sometimes, those "bugs" are unintentionally hilarious. I once discovered a flying ship in Miami. Yep. A ship. Flying. I didn't even bother reporting it, at this point, I just waved at the captain and moved on. Honestly, it's part of the charm.

So yes, [b]Free Flight mode? Fantastic. 8.5/10 easy.[/b]

[h3]Then there's Career Mode.[/h3]
[b]And oh boy… where do I even begin?[/b]

Calling it "buggy" would be like calling a hurricane "a bit windy."
If you can imagine a bug...any bug...it's there!

The game will find creative new ways to fail you.
A pigeon sneezes in another time zone? [b]Penalty.[/b]
A cloud gives you side-eye? [b]Mission failed.[/b]
Someone in your house opens a soda can too loud? [b]Congratulations, you're out of fuel.[/b]
And my personal favorite: ATC instructs you to maintain 5,000 feet while you're staring straight at a 10,000 foot mountain. If you climb...[b]Penalty.[/b]

It doesn't matter if you're on Xbox Game Pass or Steam, I've tested both, the madness is the exact same. You could be flying over the Himalayas or taking off from Kansas, at any moment, something small, random, and ridiculous [b]will[/b] ruin the entire flight.

Here's the thing:
I want to love Career Mode. The concept is brilliant. Building a flying career, taking jobs, improving your rank, it's everything a flight sim enthusiast dreams of. But right now, it feels more like a test of patience than a feature. Each time I think "Okay, maybe this update fixed it," I end up going to bed frustrated, muttering at my monitor like an air traffic controller who's lost faith in humanity.

And what's worse? I've seen almost no meaningful bug fixes in the updates so far.
Every patch feels like a new paint job on a plane with one wing missing.
No serious acknowledgment from the devs, no clear roadmap for major fixes, and definitely no hint of an "MSFS2026" or future plan. That's what really scares me, that this might be as good as it gets for Career Mode.

Will I keep playing?
[b] Absolutely. [/b]
Because when everything does work, when the wind is calm, the systems behave, and the plane glides smoothly through golden-hour light, it's truly pure magic. Those moments remind me why I fell in love with flight sims in the first place.

But most evenings, after a long day of work, I just want to relax, fly a job, and make a little progress… and instead I end up staring at "Mission Failed" screen, questioning my life choices and wondering if my dog's snoring somehow triggered a stall warning.

Bottom line:
I can't, from the deepest part of my aviation-loving soul, give this game a positive review.
Because I care too much to pretend it's fine.

Games are not just about graphics, they're about experience, consistency, and respect for the player's time. And right now, Career Mode doesn't respect any of that.

If you're still tempted to buy it (and hey, I get it), do yourself a favor:
Head to the official forums at forums.flightsimulator.com
Take a read. See what the community is saying. You'll quickly realize this isn't just me ranting into the void, it's a chorus of frustrated pilots trying to love a game that keeps stalling mid-flight.

Thank you and Happy Flying everyone
